entry.title: The 3 Pillars of Cloud Computing
entry.content:
1. IaaS – Infrastructure as a Service

IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service) is the most “basic” layer of the cloud. Think of it as renting virtual computers, storage, and networks. You don’t need to buy physical servers—just pay for what you use, and scale resources up or down as needed.

  • Who’s in control: The user controls the operating system, storage, and applications, but doesn’t have to worry about the hardware.

  • Real-world example: Netflix uses Amazon Web Services (AWS) to host its servers. This allows them to handle massive global traffic without stressing over physical server maintenance.

SAP Solution:
SAP HANA Enterprise Cloud (HEC) is SAP’s IaaS offering. It lets companies migrate their SAP environments to a managed, high-performance, secure, and scalable cloud infrastructure. No need to worry about server maintenance, backups, or updates—SAP handles it all.

2. PaaS – Platform as a Service

PaaS (Platform as a Service) is like the “middle ground.” In addition to infrastructure, it offers tools and environments for developing, testing, and hosting applications. Developers don’t have to worry about OS updates or database installs—it’s all included!

  • Who’s in control: The user manages only apps and data. The provider handles everything else (infrastructure, OS, updates).

  • Real-world example: Spotify uses Google Cloud Platform (GCP) and its PaaS services to develop and roll out new features fast, focusing solely on code and user data.

SAP Solution:
SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is the core of SAP’s PaaS solutions. Developers can build SAP system extensions, create intelligent apps with AI, analyze data in real time, and integrate multiple data sources. BTP provides resources for databases, advanced analytics, system integration, and app development—all in the cloud.

3. SaaS – Software as a Service

SaaS (Software as a Service) is the most familiar model for end-users. Here, you don’t install anything on your computer—just access the software via the internet, using a browser or app. Everything—infrastructure, platform, and app—is managed by the provider.

  • Who’s in control: The user simply uses the software, with no worries about installation, updates, or infrastructure.

  • Real-world example: Gmail, Google Docs, and Salesforce are classic examples. Companies like Coca-Cola use Salesforce to manage global sales securely and at scale, without having to maintain their own servers.

SAP Solutions:
This is where SAP is a global powerhouse! Some top examples:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud: A modern, intelligent cloud ERP for managing finance, operations, and more.

  • SAP SuccessFactors: A full-suite HR solution for talent management, payroll, performance, and training.

  • SAP Ariba: A complete cloud-based procurement and supplier management platform, streamlining purchasing processes.

Each of these solutions is designed for specific needs, helping companies become more digital, agile, and competitive.

How Each Pillar Delivers Data Protection

When it comes to cloud computing, security is always a top concern for companies. Sensitive data and critical operations are now managed outside your four walls. SAP knows this and invests heavily to ensure robust protection in every cloud layer: IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS. Here’s how security is managed in each:

1. IaaS (SAP HANA Enterprise Cloud)

With IaaS, SAP secures the entire infrastructure, while clients manage their apps and data.

Top security practices:

  • Certified data centers: SAP uses global data centers certified to international standards (like ISO 27001).

  • Firewalls and network segmentation: Digital barriers keep client data isolated and prevent unauthorized access.

  • Data encryption: Both in transit (on the network) and at rest (on servers).

  • Continuous monitoring: SIEM tools and 24/7 expert teams detect threats in real time.

Client’s responsibility: Manage user access to apps and maintain internal security policies.

2. PaaS (SAP Business Technology Platform)

With PaaS, SAP secures the platform (infrastructure, middleware, databases), while clients secure the applications they build.

Top security practices:

  • Identity and access management: Granular control over who can access what, including multi-factor authentication.

  • Isolated environments: Client apps run in separate spaces to prevent cross-company data leaks.

  • Compliance tools: Automated auditing, logs, and controls to meet regulations like GDPR.

  • Automatic updates: The platform is always up-to-date with the latest security patches.

Client’s responsibility: Ensure secure app development practices, like input validation and permissions management.

3. SaaS (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SuccessFactors, Ariba)

With SaaS, SAP manages almost all aspects of security and delivers ready-to-use, protected solutions.

Top security practices:

  • End-to-end encryption: Secures all communication and stored data.

  • Role-based access controls: Users only see the info needed for their role.

  • Backup and disaster recovery: Automated routines guarantee data restoration if something goes wrong.

  • Compliance monitoring: Integrated tools to ensure global regulatory adherence (SOX, GDPR, LGPD).

Client’s responsibility: Set user access policies, review security settings, and promote internal security awareness.

Conclusion

SAP stands out for offering a complete range of cloud solutions, so companies can pick what fits best—whether it’s infrastructure, a platform, or ready-to-use software. This flexibility lets you innovate, grow, and keep your eyes on what really matters: your business results.

Understanding the differences between IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS helps companies choose the right solution for every stage or need. Cloud computing makes it possible to scale on demand, pay only for what you use, and avoid infrastructure headaches.

Want to see more examples or need tips on choosing the right model for your project? Just ask!

Sources:

entry.title: Extend a Custom Business Object created with Key User Extensibility using SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
This blog post covers how to setup an extension scenario from SAP S/4HANA Cloud and build Side-by-Side UI Extensions with the help of SAP Build Apps in the Business Technology Platform.

Business scenario:

A Manager wants to define business objects “Bonus Plan” for employees. A Bonus Plan is there to save employee specific rules for bonus entitlement.

Here, with Key User Extensibility, we create a custom Business Object with a data structure, logic for data initialization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition which should have standard API operations (GET, POST, DELETE). Expose the custom business object as web service for side-by-side UI extension using Low-code No-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will learn how quickly a new UI application can be developed with the no-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will also find out what is the process to setup, develop and deploy a productive extension application.

Note: The maintain Bonus app shown in this blog is for educational purpose only and not meant for productive usage. It is not ensured that the data used in this extension scenario is managed in accordance with applicable legal requirements for all countries and industries and in accordance with the business needs, such as data life cycle requirements.  

Prerequisites:

  1. Subscription to SAP Build Apps on SAP BTP Sub-Account
  2. Your user needs (a) business role(s) with business catalogs Extensibility - Custom Business Objects (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CBO), Extensibility - Custom Communication Scenarios (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CCS) and Communication Management (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_COM) (Need to have unrestricted access if you are creating a business role and adding these catalogs).
  3. You have Created Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud as per the given tutorial.                                                                

Why SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA Cloud?

Create new solutions using the secure, no-code SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA. Build visually and empower users to digitalise their daily work without impacting core processes. Create a personalised, accessible application that securely connects to data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

To extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud using SAP Build Apps, you can leverage side-by-side extensibility, which allows you to build extensions that run on SAP BTP and interact with your S/4HANA Cloud system. This approach enables you to create custom UIs, logic, and integrations without directly modifying the core S/4HANA Cloud system. 

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Let’s start on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud side with the definition of the Custom Business Object and the communication settings.

Custom Business Object

In the Create Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud tutorial group it is shown how to create a custom business object and generate a UI (user interface) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Expose Custom Business Object as External API

To integrate custom business object from SAP S/4HANA system with External Systems or Services like SAP Build Apps, as administrator you need to create a Communication Arrangement. You create a communication arrangement to enable the communication between your system and SAP Build App in BTP, and how they communicate. Communication Arrangement is formed by combining the below artifacts:

  1. Creating a Custom Communication Scenario
    The setup of the communication (inbound and outbound) between SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP starts with the definition of a Custom Communication Scenario.
    The Custom Communication Scenario contains the information for both inbound and outbound HTTP-calls.
    • Open the app Custom Communication Scenarios in the Launchpad of the SAP S/4 HANA system and create a new Custom Communication Scenario with the name YY1_BONUSPLAN.

     

    • On the tab Inbound Services, you create an entry for your Custom Business Object: Press Add button to add inbound service “YY1_BONUSPLAN_CDS” and click select button. 

     

    • Press Save and Publish to finish the custom communication scenario creation.

     

  2. Creating a Communication System and User

    To enable secure communication between different systems you have to register these systems and define the user which is authorized to use the connection.

    The communication system represents the communication partner within a communication. for inbound communication, this is the external system that calls our custom Bonus plan service.

    We’ll create one Communication System for all systems that want to use our service as well as the user that they’ll have to use. If you want to access the custom BONUSPLAN OData service (Inbound) you also need to setup an authentication method. You can use several methods like e.g.., Basic Authentication, Certificate or OAuth.

    In this case we are choosing Basic Authentication for which you need to setup a Communication User. Open the app Maintain Communication Users from the Communication Management group and create there a new user with username, description, and password.

    • Open “Communication Systems” Application.
    • Start creating a new system by executing the “New” action.
    • Give following data to the new custom communication System…

    Note: you can replace XXX with your system ID.

    Field Label

    Field Value

    System ID

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    System Name

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    • Scroll down to “User for Inbound Communication” and start adding one by executing the “Add” action.
    • In the Pop Up, use the value help to browse and select the user.

     

    • Choose the user you already created and then click OK. Your user for Inbound Communication is set up. Click on Save.

  3. Creating a Communication Arrangement for Custom Communication Scenario

Finally, a communication arrangement links the solution’s scenario with the Communication system and its user and exposes the Service to be used.

  • Open “Communication Arrangements” Application
  • Start creation by executing the “New” action.
  • A pop up opens in that you use the value help for Scenario first where you can select previously created Custom Communication Scenario YY1_BONUSPLAN. This will set the Scenario and default the Arrangement Name, so that you can continue the creation via “Create” button.

  • In the opening Arrangement details click to browse the Communication System
  • Choose the EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX you created before.
  • Choosing the system will automatically set the related User as well. Click Save to finish creation
  • Copy the Service URL for the next step. Here you save the inbound service URL for the destination configuration in BTP.

 

 

 

 

 


Build Side-by-Side UI Extensibility with SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps enables developers to implement loosely coupled extension applications securely on top of the existing SAP solution they already have. SAP Build Apps provides drag-and-drop capabilities for Citizen developers to build enterprise-grade applications confidently, authenticate and access SAP Business Technology Platform destinations. You can preview your SAP Build Apps project as web preview and can build it to deploy on SAP Build Work Zone or Android/IOS.

Here you will learn how to use SAP Build Apps, create an app that performs all the CRU (Create, Read, Update) operations for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud BONUSPLAN API for managing the Bonus Plan for the employee.

The point of this tutorial is to show you how you would perform all the CRU (Create, Read, Update) operations, and how you would handle some of the complexities of the SAP backend APIs (e.g. strict requirements for the data and handle multiple determination) for the Bonus plan scenario.

You will create an app with 2 pages:

  • Page 1: Display all Bonus plans
  • Page 2: Manage Bonus Plan, which handles Create or Update the bonus plan for employees.

Create destination to SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.   

In the SAP BTP cockpit, as administrator you need to create a destination to enable the communication to the S/4HANA Cloud system. In addition, the destination must be enabled for use in SAP Build Apps.

Open SAP Build Apps

In the lobby of your SAP Build Apps, click Create.

Select Frontend and followed by this Select Web & Mobile Application and press Next button. Please note that the user needs to have access to the Custom Identity Provider to be able to create a Web & Mobile Application.

For the project name, enter Bonus plan Management and description as “Extend a key user extension from S/4HANA Cloud public edition “then click Create.

 

Connect to the REST API from the Custom Business Object on S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In this step, you will make a connection to the BONUSPLAN API of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system. You will enable entities: BONUSPLAN (the header for a BONUSPLAN)

  2. Click Add Integration.
  3. Click BTP Destinations, and then select the destination to your SAP S/4HANA Cloud BONUSPLAN API which you have created in “Create destination to SAP S/4HANA Cloud system” section.
  4. Select Click Install Integration (upper right).
  5. Under Data Entities, scroll down so you can see both YY1_BONUSPLAN and I_Currency. For each, select it and click Enable Data Entity.
  6. You can now select an entity and click Browse Real Data to see live data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.


  7. Click Save (upper right).



Create page for displaying BONUSPLANs (Homepage)

Now you will create the home page that displays a list of Bonus Plans, for which the user can update the existing Bonus Plan and can create a new Bonus Plan.

entry.title: Review Booklet (Template) In Margin Analysis For Company Profitability Reporting
entry.content:
Motivation

 In SAP Cloud ERP 2508, SAP delivered a new review booklet (template) in Margin Analysis for Company Profitability reporting, showing a 3-level Contribution Margin for a Company Code.

In this article I will   explain the purpose of the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) app, how the data for the margin levels is selected, and how you can use the template out of the box.

What Can the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) App Do For You?

The booklet provides Management Accounting insights, which are not yet available on a structured and aggregated level.

It allows a multi-dimensional analysis of contribution margins on 3 levels using Margin Analysis relevant attributes.

 The booklet technology offers highly adaptable financial reporting based on actual postings (ACODCA). This ensures that users have access to precise and detailed information, enhancing decision-making processes.

With advanced formatting options, users can customize reports to suit their needs. The technology also supports downloading and collaboration features, making it easier for teams to work together seamlessly.

As technology advances, so does the booklet. It incorporates AI features, ensuring that users benefit from the latest innovations in financial reporting.

The booklet has standard extensibility functionality to enable adoptability via key user apps.

Contribution Margin Measure Structure And The Reason It Is Called A Template

SAP uses the Functional Areas from Best Practice Content, so the selection needs to be adjusted by customers.

That is why it is called a Template.

If you use the SAP delivered Function Areas (YB18 to YB50) in your cost objects, you can use the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) app out of the box.

If not, you need to adjust the selection in the CDS Analytical Query using Key User tools.

I will explain this in another blog.

Key Capabilities

The new review booklet is delivered with SAP Cloud ERP 2508.

It is based on SAP Best Practices Contribution Margin Financial Statement Version (FSV) YPS2 and its semantic tags.

It shows 3 levels of Contribution Margin:
I           Revenues / Related variable costs
II          / Related fixed costs, warranties and variances
III         / Company periodic costs

The booklet is cross-industry, so it can read different account assignments:

  • Market Segments (EO) for Sales Order etc.
  • Projects (PR), with all attributes
  • Service Contracts/Orders (SC, SV), with all attributes
  • Cost Centers (KS, KL) and Orders (OR) for non-allocated costs

With Universal Journal integration we can read costs directly from those cost objects including the attributed Margin Analysis dimensions. There is no need to settle or allocate costs to Market Segments.

Figure 1: Year-to-date comparison of 3-level contribution margin for a company code

 The hierarchical structure of the measures is hard coded in the underlying CDS Analytical Query.

Each measure has semantic tags assigned from FSV YPS2, so GL Account assignments can be adjusted in configuration. You can use your own FSV, but you must use the same semantic tags.

Fixed/variable costs are read from the ACDOCA amount fields.

 you also need to select additional ACDOCA dimensions for the following measures to get correct amounts:

  • Functional Area (to distinguish between COGS and periodic costs)
  • Billable Control (remove warranty costs)
  • Subledger Line Item Type (to distinguish production variances)

Figure 2: Hierarchical measure structure for the 3-level contribution margin

 Data Selection In Detail

The system reads actual revenue and cost in Company Code currency from ACDOCA using the cube I_GLAcctLineItemSemTagGLAcct with Semantic Tags

 You can access all Margin Analysis data from a set of Cost Objects. Select the Account Assignment Type as follows:

  • EO (Market Segment)
  • PR (Project)
  • SV (Service Order Item)
  • SC (Service Contract)
  • OR (Order)
  • KS (Cost Center)
  • VB (Sales Document Item)
  • KL (Cost Center and Activity)

 You need to distinguish the measures between Read (RKF) and Calculated (Calc) figures.

Calculated figures are based on Read Key Figures and just have a calculation formula without selection criteria.

The Read Key Figures always use a Semantic Tag in the selection.

Please refer to the full list, to get an overview.

Figure 3: List of calculated and read key figures with selection criteria

The reason why additional selection on some figures is required is because SAP uses the Semantic Tag PL_RESULT on several RKFs. PL_RESULT contains all G/L Accounts maintained in the financial statement version.

To ensure we do not count costs on the same account in several key figures, we need to restrict further.

Periodic Costs

Let’s have a look at the periodic costs first. We want to distinguish periodic costs into the following:

  • Marketing
  • Sales
  • Administration
  • Research & Development

 There are 4 different measures using the Semantic Tag PL_RESULT.

We added the delivered Best Practices FSV YPS2 some more Primary Cost G/L Accounts with SAP Cloud ERP 2508 under a new node called Common Operational Cost Gls (Node ID 74). Please check if you need additional G/L Accounts and add them. If you were a customer before SAP Cloud ERP 2508, you will need to add this node and all G/L Accounts you want to see costs under PL_RESULT.

 The PL_RESULT tag is used here (all costs) to ensure we also see costs in the report that are not being allocated to Margin Analysis using Universal Allocation or Settlement. Primary costs remain on Cost Centers or WBS Element. We could restrict via a Semantic Tag to the corresponding allocation or settlement G/L accounts, if settlement and allocation were done from all object using the secondary G/L Accounts, but this is rarely the case.

 To ensure we have different costs summed on the 4 measures, we use the Functional Areas from Best Practices:

  • YB35: Marketing
  • YB30: Sales
  • YB40: Administration
  • YB50: Research & Development

The Functional Area is always filled in ACDOCA and derived from the Cost Object (Cost Center, WBS Element) on which the periodic costs are posted.

Of course, we continue to display periodic costs allocated or settled to Market Segments. Users can then also drill down into the used dimensions like Product or Customer Group. The system credits allocated costs to the cost center without the Market Segment dimension. This ensures that costs do not appear twice in the total.

 

Figure 4: Example for allocated and non-allocated periodic costs by G/L account in the review booklet

 

Price Differences (Or Production Variances)

A similar case is Price Difference or Production Variance, which can occur on Production Orders and are posted to Market Segment dimensions of a Production Order, once it is completed.

We want to distinguish variance into the following:

  • Input Price
  • Input Quantity
  • Resource Usage
  • Lot Size
  • Output Price
  • Input Remaining

So, we have different Read Key Figures all with Semantic Tag PL_RESULT, since different variance can occur on the same G/L Account.

Therefore, we use the Sub-ledger Line Item Type to further restrict the different amounts.

It is filled by production variance calculation in ACDOCA when posted to Market Segments.

Warranty Costs

We also want to show warranty costs as a measure using Semantic Tag PL_RESULT, since all kinds of G/L Account can carry warranty cost.

For all warranty costs, the Billable Control (or Accounting Indicator ACDOCA-BEMOT) is filled to configurable values like “Non-Billable Demand” or “Goodwill”. This allows us to read with Billable Control not initial.

All Other Costs Of Good Sold

For all other COGS measures in our structure, we make use of the fix and variable separation in ACDOCA and have different sematic tags.

In addition, we use the Best Practice Functional Areas

  • YB18: Cost of Goods Sold
  • YB25: Consulting/Services

 To ensure we only count product and service-related costs in the Contribution Margin I and II we also restrict to Billable Control/Accounting Indicator is initial to not include warranty costs.

 Revenues And Sales Deductions

For revenue and sales deduction figures, it is enough to read the semantic tags and assigned G/L Accounts without the Functional Area.

Navigation to Line-Item Reporting

To verify the aggregated data, users can navigate to the line-item report for Margin Analysis. They can then filter using the criteria for each measure. Semantic tags are resolved into G/L Account through navigation.

Other filters are kept as defined.

Figure 5: Navigation to Display Line Items – Margin Analysis to  measure warranty costs

Figure 6: Filters in Display Line Items – Margin Analysis to measure warranty costs

The sum in the line-item report should fit the figure in the booklet, with the following limitations:

  • For Fixed/Variable Cost measures, you can verify only the Fixed Amount and need to calculate the Variable as Total minus Fixed.  This is available only for Group Currency.
  • If the booklet includes additional page filters for fields which are not available as filters in the line-item report (e.g. for fiscal quarter), the sum might not match.

Conclusion And Outlook

You now understand the purpose and logic of the booklet and know when you need to adopt.

We would highly appreciate your feedback on this article.

In future we plan to add additional features to the booklet, e.g.

  • Display of amounts in Group Currency
  • Selection and comparison of several Company Codes
  • Commenting
  • Business Insights powered by AI

entry.title: Best practices for keeping up with the SAP Activate content updates
entry.content:
In this post, I intend to share practices and resources that will help you stay in step with the rapid and regular updates in the SAP Activate road maps that SAP delivers to our customers both on the SAP Activate road map viewer (link) and in the SAP Cloud ALM application. We deliver these updates to keep the implementation guidance in step with the innovations introduced in the product and to give our users the latest, up-to-date guidance and accelerators that help them run their transformation projects better. Most of our road maps are on a bi-weekly update cycle, and in some updates, we deliver minor refinements of the content that users may not even notice, while in other updates, we introduce significant updates to support our users in adopting new capabilities.

For example earlier in this year when SAP released Parallel Line capability to all our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public customers on 3-system landscape, the SAP Activate guidance delivered several new tasks and accelerators to help our users to learn about this new capability, request provisioning of the parallel line tenants and explanation on how to use this functionality for parallel configuration activities and how to use transports in this parallel line. There are also examples for the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private, where some of our latest additions were bringing the guidance for use of WalkMe, refinement of the Clean Core Quality Gates, and new content for RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard. To name just a few.

Now, how can we best keep up with these ongoing updates? There are two main sources for information, one in each of our tools, where SAP delivers SAP Activate to our users. Let’s start with the SAP Activate in the road map viewer.

Release notes in the SAP Activate road map viewer

For the most frequently updated SAP Activate road maps, like SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition or SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private, you can find dedicated release notes on the Overview page of the road map in the application. See the screenshot below with the highlighted section where you can access the release notes.

When you open the link, you will download a document with release notes that are updated every time we release a new update. These notes provide an overview of the key updates delivered with the new content release. This document is a great source for staying up to date with the new content delivered in each update. You can review it on a regular basis to stay up to date on all the key updates delivered in the SAP Activate road map.

Detailed content update summary in SAP Cloud ALM

Users of SAP Cloud ALM may have noticed a tile “SAP Content Update Summary” in the Project Overview app (see the screenshot below). The tile provides detailed information about how many tasks have been updated (blue bubble), how many new tasks were delivered in the content update (light gray bubble), and how many tasks have been deprecated (dark gray bubble).

The user can click on each bubble to go to the detailed task list for each category (see the screenshot below). In this screen, you can open the task details by selecting it, assess whether it is relevant to your project, and accordingly assign it to the user or team. If it is not relevant, mark it as such with the status “Not Relevant.”

Now, let’s look at the “Updated” tasks. We will access the task list the same way we did in the previous step from the Project Overview screen. Then, in the list, we can pick one task to review the details of the change. You will access the “History” details by selecting the “…” at the top right side of the screen and selecting the “History” item from the menu (see below).

The history opens to the right of the task. In this section of the screen, you can select the time frame for the history (filter button on the right) or change the sorting how the history is shown (sort button on the left). The sorting will present the history from the latest changes at the top (default) or you can change it to see the oldest changes at the top.

This way, you can see all the detailed changes of the content that have been delivered to your project. Like in the example for new tasks, you can assess if the updated task is relevant for your project and if the assigned owner can carry it out. Use the Status and Comments on the task to keep track of your actions and communication with the task owner.

Note that this capability works for both projects created with single SAP Activate roadmap as well as the projects utilizing combined roadmaps in SAP Cloud ALM. In our example, we used a combined roadmap with content from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3-system landscape, SAP SuccessFactors, the Adoption Plan for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP Concur.

I hope that this blog post helped you understand how to best utilize the release notes and detailed content history in SAP Cloud ALM to keep yourself up to date on the release updates and your project task list. Please share your feedback in the comments and let me know if you already use these features and what your experience is.
